messageBody:
On Thu, 2003-04-03 at 17:34, Michael Rettig wrote:
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "artisanzero" <peter.pascale@...>
> Date: Thu, 03 Apr 2003 21:14:38 -0000
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Planning Unit Tests
>
> > A group of developers were recently asked whether an additional 10%
> > of design/code time was adequate to write unit tests. I'm interested
> > in feedback regarding what others think is adequate. I am not
> > interested in why the question itself is incorrect, I know that. If
> > you were shown a project plan, told that unit tests weren't worked
> > into the schedule, but that they should be, and asked what percentage
> > of time should be added - what would you say. Keep in mind the
> > positive - management wants unit tests included and is willing to
> > consider allotting time.
> >
> > Any thoughts?
>
> Automated Unit Tests DO NOT add to the length of a project. Add 10% to the project plan if you are not "allowed" to write unit tests. This number increases exponentially over the life of the project. Take at Beck's XP Explained for a proper discussion on managing the cost of change curve.
>
> When faced with this question, I give two estimates. One with unit testing, and one without. The one without unit testing is always substantially larger. If the estimate is predetermined, then you need to cut scope or extend the timeline. If you have no power to negotiate, then prepare for a deathmarch.
>
> Hope this helps.
>
> Mike Rettig

However, if the developers on the project aren't familiar with unit
testing or whatever tool you're going to use, there will be a time cost
for them to come up to speed. People new to unit testing will almost
certainly code slower than usual while they get used to it. How much
this will impact the project depends on how long term the project is.

Of course, the payoffs for this are huge, so this shouldn't discourage
you.

Tom
